
648,5,1,2011,Food and Agriculture<br>,Nutrition,Farm Direct Foods,Community,(Abstract - Creates rules by which producers or farmers may sell agricultural products directly to consumers including at farmers markets.  Includes rules for direct to consumer sales for fruits vegetables and nuts.  ) (BillHistory - )

650,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Initiatives and Programs,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)
651,5,1,2010,Farmers' Markets: Electronic Benefit Transfers,Nutrition,Fruits and Vegetables,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Allows an interested collective group or association of produce sellers that is Food and Nutrition Service authorized and in a flea market farmers' market or certified farmers' market to initiate and operate an electronic benefit transfer system acceptance system in the market. Provides that an individual produce seller in a market is not prohibited from operating his or her own individual system acceptance activity as part of that seller's personal business customer transaction offering. ) (BillHistory - 02/25/2009 - INTRODUCED.;03/12/2009 - To ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE.;04/01/2009 - From ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE with author's amendments.;04/01/2009 - In ASSEMBLY. 653,5,1,2014,Transit Village Plan,Physical Activity,Bicycling,Community,(Abstract - Allows a city or county to prepare a village development plan. Authorizes the authority to provide funding subject to the Department of Transportation's approval for repair and maintenance of state highways within its boundaries. 661,5,1,2009,Transportation: Bicycle Routes of Regional Significance,Nutrition,Medical Care,Community,(Abstract - Enacts the Bicycle Routes of National State or Regional Significance Act. Authorizes the Department of Transportation to establish a process for identifying and promoting bicycle routes of national state or regional significance. Authorizes the establishment of a process to nominate a route. Authorizes the department to form a related advisory committee. Authorizes the installation of bicycle route signs identifying these routes. Provides applicants or nominating parties may pay the cost for route signs.) 663,5,1,2007,Pupil Nutrition: Trans Fat,Nutrition,Trans Fats,School/After School,(Abstract - Prohibits a school or school district through a vending machine or school food service establishment during school hours and up to 1/2 hour before and after school hours from making available to pupils in kindergarten or any of grades 1 to 12 inclusive a food containing artificial trans fat. Prohibits the use of artificial trans fat in the preparation of a food item served to those pupils. Excludes food provided as part of a USDA meal program.) 669,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Food Restrictions,Medical and/or Hospital,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Provides for low income housing to have access to: transit; a public park; a full scale grocery store/supermarket where staples fresh meat and fresh produce are sold; and a weekly farmers market.) 677,5,1,2005,Parks: The Great California Delta Trail System,Physical Activity,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Requires the Delta Protection Commission to establish a continuous recreation corridor including a bicycle and hiking trails around the the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta. Authorizes the transportation planning agencies that allocate funds to the cities and counties within jurisdiction or a sphere of influence within the Delta to allocate funds to the commission for specified activities around the Delta. Requires the plan to link the San Francisco Bay Trail system to planned Sacramento River trails.) 678,5,1,2005,Playground Safety Standards,Physical Activity,Parks Recreation and Trails,Community,(Abstract - Repeals the laws governing playground safety standards. Requires the Department of Social Services to convene a working group to make recommendation to the Legislature for minimum safety requirements for playgrounds equipment and surfaces. Requires all new playgrounds which were opened to the public during a specified time frame to conform to standards set by the American Society for Testing and Materials and the guidelines set by the United State Consumer Product Safety Commission.) 681,5,1,2008,Food Facilities: Nutritional Information,Obesity,Menu Labeling,Community,"(Abstract - ""Amends the General Uniform Retail Food Facilities Law. Requires each food facility to either disclose nutritional information or calorie count information. Requires that on and after another date each food facility in the state that meets specified criteria shall disclose calorie content information per standard menu item. Provides that a food facility that violates the provisions of the bill is guilty of an infraction. Prohibits local governments from regulating disclosure of nutritional information."") 711,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Health Insurance Coverage,School/After School,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 713,5,1,2010,Federal and State Low Income Housing Tax Credit Laws,Nutrition,Liability and Indemnity,Community,(Abstract - Amends rules regarding the procedures for reservation allocation and compliance monitoring of the Federal and State Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs and establishes policies and procedures for use of the Tax Credits to meet purposes of the Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Provides for low income housing to have access to: transit; a public park; a full scale grocery store/supermarket where staples fresh meat and fresh produce are sold; and a weekly farmers market.) 725,5,1,2016,The Lower Los Angeles River Recreation and Park District.,Physical Activity,Parks Recreation and Trails,Community,(Abstract - This bill would specifically authorize the establishment of the Lower Los Angeles River Recreation and Park District by petition or resolution submitted to the Los Angeles County Local Agency Formation Commission before January 1 2019 subject to specified existing laws governing recreation and park districts including their formation except as provided. The bill would specify that the district has financing authority under existing law and would further prescribe additional functions and duties of the district including but not limited to the acquisition construction improvement maintenance and operation of open space and parks along the Lower Los Angeles River.) (BillHistory - Introduced  02/19/2016Amended    04/05/2016Amended   04/05/2016Passed   08/30/2016Approved  09/22/2016)

735,5,1,2014,Bikeways,Physical Activity,Bicycling,Community,(Abstract - Adds the definition of Class IV bikeways to the Protected Bikeways Act of 2014. Cycle tracks or separated bikeways promote active transportation and provide a right-of-way designated exclusively for bicycle travel adjacent to a roadway and which are protected from vehicular traffic. Types of separation include but are not limited to grade separation flexible posts inflexible physical barriers or on-street parking.) 741,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Public Safety,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 752,5,1,2005,Free or Reduce-Price Meals,Nutrition,Appropriations,School/After School,(Abstract - Requires a waiver from the requirement that a school district or county superintendent of schools provide each needy pupil one nutritionally adequate free or reduced-price mean during each school day to be granted if a Summer Food Service Program is available within a specified proximity to the schoolsite and as to specified hours of operation or if compliance with the requirement would result in a specified financial loss. Authorizes a district or county superintendent to use certain funds.) 754,5,1,2007,Wave Pools,Obesity,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Enacts the Wave Pool Safety Act. Requires a wave pool operator to comply with several safety requirements to include providing a US Coast Guard-approved Type II or III lifevest that is free and available for use by any nonswimmer specified children or any patron upon request. Requires certain children to wear the vest in order to gain access to a pool. Requires an audible signal to be used before the breaking wave action resumes to warn patrons. Requires specified signs and lifeguards.) 757,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Marketing Restrictions,Work Place,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)

776,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Initiatives and Programs,Community,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 781,5,1,2011,An Act Related to Food Banks<br>,Nutrition,Incentives,Community,"(Abstract - Establishes the State Emergency Food Assistance Program (“Program”).  Requires the Program to procure healthy local foods especially fruits and vegetables and provide them to food banks in order to serve low-income and minority families at-risk for huger and hunger-related illnesses including obesity.  Allows a tax credit for private citizens who donate healthy foods to the Program.) Provides for funding for safety paths for pedestrian use beyond two immediately adjacent sides of the site necessary for a safe route to the new school site when certain conditions are met.) 783,5,1,2011,Food and Agriculture: Omnibus Bill,Nutrition,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Deletes obsolete reporting requirements of the Food Biotechnology Task Force. Defines the term business day for purposes of provisions of existing law relating to the impounding of stray dogs or cats in a shelter. Relates to the per diem allowance for members of the State Walnut Commission. Relates to employee contracting by the 50th District Agricultural Association or a related joint powers agency. The advisory committee shall consist of representatives from consumer groups environmental organizations farmers ranchers representatives from the biotechnology industry researchers organic farmers food processors retailers and others with interests in the issues surrounding biotechnology.  ) (BillHistory - 02/01/2011 - INTRODUCED.;02/10/2011 - To ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE.;04/06/2011 - From ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE:  Do pass as amended. 790,5,1,2007,Wave Pools,Physical Activity,Signage for Recreation and Transportation,Community,(Abstract - Enacts the Wave Pool Safety Act. Requires a wave pool operator to comply with several safety requirements to include providing a US Coast Guard-approved Type II or III lifevest that is free and available for use by any nonswimmer specified children or any patron upon request. Requires certain children to wear the vest in order to gain access to a pool. Requires an audible signal to be used before the breaking wave action resumes to warn patrons. Requires specified signs and lifeguards.) 792,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Access to Healthy Foods,School/After School,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)
793,5,1,2007,Food Facilities: Trans Fat,Nutrition,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Requires every food facility except a school cafeteria to maintain on the label for any food or food additive that is or includes any fat oil or shortening for as long as this food or food additive is stored distributed or served by or used in the preparation of food within the food facility. Prohibits on or after a specified date oil shortening or margarine containing specified trans fats for specified purposes from being stored distributed or served by or used in the preparation of food.) 794,5,1,2007,Physical Education: Volunteer Instructors,Obesity,Appropriations,School/After School,(Abstract - Authorizes a school district and a county office of education to establish a registry of volunteer after school physical recreation instructors. Provides that to be included on a registry a prospective registrant would be required to submit to a criminal background check and submit certain information. Authorizes a district or office maintaining a registry to impose other requirements on prospective registrants. Provides that such physical recreation would not count towards graduation.) 797,5,1,2014,Distinguished After School Health (DASH) Recognition Program,Obesity,Sugar Sweetened Beverages,School/After School,"(Abstract - Establishes the ""Distinguished After School Health (DASH) recognition program"" to certify and train staff on the importance of modeling healthy eating and physical activity. It requires the program to provide regular and ongoing nutrition education ensure that each program attendee participates on a daily basis in an average of 30 to 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity screen time is limited during the operational hours of the after school program and is only allowed in connection with homework or an activity that engages program attendees in a physical activity or educational experience and that healthy foods including fruits or vegetables without added sugar are served to program attendees as snacks on a daily basis. Attendees are to be served water low-fat or nonfat milk nonfat flavored milk or 100 percent fruit juice. Sugar-sweetened beverages are not served to program attendees and staff of the after school program do not consume sugar-sweetened beverages at the after school program site. shall remain in effect only until January 1 2018 unless a later enacted statute that is enacted before January 1 2018 deletes or extends that date.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2014 INTRODUCED.02/20/2014 To SENATE Committees on HEALTH and EDUCATION.04/02/2014 From SENATE Committee on HEALTH: Do pass as amended to Committee on EDUCATION.04/08/2014 In SENATE. 800,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Food Restrictions,School/After School,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. 817,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Access to Healthy Foods,Work Place,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Encourages public schools maintaining kindergarten or any of grades 1 to 12 inclusive to provide fruits and vegetables that have not been deep fried to pupils in order to promote the consumption of such foods by schoolage children. Provides funds for an online professional development course for staff on serving marketing and promoting nutritious fruits and vegetables and a contract to conduct a comprehensive evaluation.) Authorizes the Board of Supervisors of the City and County of San Francisco to designate a board or agency to act as the transportation management agency for Treasure Island defined to also include Yerba Buena Island. Specifies the powers and duties of the agency.) 822,5,1,2010,Federal and State Low Income Housing Tax Credit Laws,Nutrition,Fruits and Vegetables,Community,(Abstract - Amends rules regarding the procedures for reservation allocation and compliance monitoring of the Federal and State Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs and establishes policies and procedures for use of the Tax Credits to meet purposes of the Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Provides for low income housing to have access to: transit; a public park; a full scale grocery store/supermarket where staples fresh meat and fresh produce are sold; and a weekly farmers market.) 824,5,1,2014,Office of Farm to Fork,Nutrition,Disparities/Equity,Community,(Abstract - Establishes and provides appropriations for the Office of Farm to Fork within the Department of Food and Agriculture which seeks to work with stakeholders within the state food system to increase the amount of agricultural products available to underserved communities (particularly urban and rural) and schools in the state. The program also seeks to identify promote the acceptance of food assistance programs such as WIC and CalFresh at certified farmer’s markets. It also includes provisions for increasing information technical assistance and resources.) 839,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Health Insurance Coverage,Medical and/or Hospital,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 869,5,1,2014,Office of Farm to Fork,Nutrition,Task Forces/Councils,School/After School,(Abstract - Establishes and provides appropriations for the Office of Farm to Fork within the Department of Food and Agriculture which seeks to work with stakeholders within the state food system to increase the amount of agricultural products available to underserved communities (particularly urban and rural) and schools in the state. The program also seeks to identify promote the acceptance of food assistance programs such as WIC and CalFresh at certified farmer’s markets. It also includes provisions for increasing information technical assistance and resources.) 870,5,1,2014,Distinguished After School Health (DASH) Recognition Program,Physical Activity,Physical Activity Requirements,School/After School,"(Abstract - Establishes the ""Distinguished After School Health (DASH) recognition program"" to certify and train staff on the importance of modeling healthy eating and physical activity. It requires the program to provide regular and ongoing nutrition education ensure that each program attendee participates on a daily basis in an average of 30 to 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity screen time is limited during the operational hours of the after school program and is only allowed in connection with homework or an activity that engages program attendees in a physical activity or educational experience and that healthy foods including fruits or vegetables without added sugar are served to program attendees as snacks on a daily basis. Attendees are to be served water low-fat or nonfat milk nonfat flavored milk or 100 percent fruit juice. Sugar-sweetened beverages are not served to program attendees and staff of the after school program do not consume sugar-sweetened beverages at the after school program site. shall remain in effect only until January 1 2018 unless a later enacted statute that is enacted before January 1 2018 deletes or extends that date.) 871,5,1,2009,Vehicles: Vehicle Length Limitations,Physical Activity,Bicycling,Community,(Abstract - Authorizes the Alameda-Contra Costa Transit District to install front-mounted bicycle racks meeting certain requirements on its buses. Requires that if the district installs the racks it would be required to report to specified legislative committees regarding safety issues and mobility improvements. Requires the district prior to installing a rack on a bus of a specified length to establish a route review committee in order to determine which routes are suitable for the safe operation of such buses.) 877,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Access to Healthy Foods,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Authorizes the transportation planning agencies that allocate funds to the cities and counties within jurisdiction or a sphere of influence within the Delta to allocate funds to the commission for specified activities around the Delta. Requires the plan to link the San Francisco Bay Trail system to planned Sacramento River trails.) 883,5,1,2013,Childhood Nutrition Training,Nutrition,Initiatives and Programs,Early Care and Education,"(Abstract - ""Amends the California Child Day Care Act to require that as a condition for licensure of a child care facility after January 1 2016 a director or teacher who receives the health and safety training also must have at least one hour of childhood nutrition training as part of the course.  Requires the training to include content on age-appropriate meal patterns.  Authorizes the Emergency Medical Services Authority to establish training through bulletins from the director until regulations are adopted."") 908,5,1,2007,Pupil Nutrition: Trans Fat,Nutrition,Appropriations,School/After School,(Abstract - Prohibits a school or school district through a vending machine or school food service establishment during school hours and up to 1/2 hour before and after school hours from making available to pupils in kindergarten or any of grades 1 to 12 inclusive a food containing artificial trans fat. Prohibits the use of artificial trans fat in the preparation of a food item served to those pupils. Excludes food provided as part of a USDA meal program.) 909,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Access to Healthy Foods,Community,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)
910,5,1,2013,School Nutrition,Nutrition,School Nutrition,School/After School,"(Abstract - ""Amends existing law to include a requirement for including a nutritious snack in the high school after-school programs and a physical activity element.  Amends the requirement banning competitive food sales to only  before or after the school day and adds skim milk and whole grains to the list of foods that may be sold.  Removes 2 percent milk from approved beverages."") 913,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Marketing Restrictions,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 928,5,1,2005,Vehicles: State Wilderness Areas,Physical Activity,Parks Recreation and Trails,Community,(Abstract - Requires a person who violates a state or federal regulation that prohibits entry of a motor vehicle into all or portion of an area designated as a federal or state wilderness area is guilty of a public offense and shall be punished by fines. Authorizes the court to order the impoundment of the vehicle used in a third or subsequent offense for a specified period of time. Prohibits assignment of a traffic violation point count to a conviction for unauthorized entry of a motor vehicle into wilderness areas.) (BillHistory - 02/22/2005 - INTRODUCED.;03/17/2005 - To ASSEMBLY Committee on WATER PARKS AND WILDLIFE.;03/31/2005 - From ASSEMBLY Committee on WATER PARKS AND WILDLIFE with author's amendments.;03/31/2005 - In ASSEMBLY. 937,5,1,2014,Distinguished After School Health (DASH) Recognition Program,Nutrition,Fruits and Vegetables,School/After School,"(Abstract - Establishes the ""Distinguished After School Health (DASH) recognition program"" to certify and train staff on the importance of modeling healthy eating and physical activity. It requires the program to provide regular and ongoing nutrition education ensure that each program attendee participates on a daily basis in an average of 30 to 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity screen time is limited during the operational hours of the after school program and is only allowed in connection with homework or an activity that engages program attendees in a physical activity or educational experience and that healthy foods including fruits or vegetables without added sugar are served to program attendees as snacks on a daily basis. Attendees are to be served water low-fat or nonfat milk nonfat flavored milk or 100 percent fruit juice. Sugar-sweetened beverages are not served to program attendees and staff of the after school program do not consume sugar-sweetened beverages at the after school program site. shall remain in effect only until January 1 2018 unless a later enacted statute that is enacted before January 1 2018 deletes or extends that date.) 939,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Initiatives and Programs,Medical and/or Hospital,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 947,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Initiatives and Programs,School/After School,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 951,5,1,2014,Distinguished After School Health (DASH) Recognition Program,Obesity,Access to Drinking Water,School/After School,"(Abstract - Establishes the ""Distinguished After School Health (DASH) recognition program"" to certify and train staff on the importance of modeling healthy eating and physical activity. It requires the program to provide regular and ongoing nutrition education ensure that each program attendee participates on a daily basis in an average of 30 to 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity screen time is limited during the operational hours of the after school program and is only allowed in connection with homework or an activity that engages program attendees in a physical activity or educational experience and that healthy foods including fruits or vegetables without added sugar are served to program attendees as snacks on a daily basis. Attendees are to be served water low-fat or nonfat milk nonfat flavored milk or 100 percent fruit juice. Sugar-sweetened beverages are not served to program attendees and staff of the after school program do not consume sugar-sweetened beverages at the after school program site. shall remain in effect only until January 1 2018 unless a later enacted statute that is enacted before January 1 2018 deletes or extends that date.) 959,5,1,2011,An Act Related to Food Banks<br>,Obesity,Initiatives and Programs,Community,"(Abstract - Establishes the State Emergency Food Assistance Program (“Program”).  Requires the Program to procure healthy local foods especially fruits and vegetables and provide them to food banks in order to serve low-income and minority families at-risk for huger and hunger-related illnesses including obesity. 984,5,1,2014,Distinguished After School Health (DASH) Recognition Program,Obesity,TV/Screen Viewing,School/After School,"(Abstract - Establishes the ""Distinguished After School Health (DASH) recognition program"" to certify and train staff on the importance of modeling healthy eating and physical activity. It requires the program to provide regular and ongoing nutrition education ensure that each program attendee participates on a daily basis in an average of 30 to 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity screen time is limited during the operational hours of the after school program and is only allowed in connection with homework or an activity that engages program attendees in a physical activity or educational experience and that healthy foods including fruits or vegetables without added sugar are served to program attendees as snacks on a daily basis. Attendees are to be served water low-fat or nonfat milk nonfat flavored milk or 100 percent fruit juice. Sugar-sweetened beverages are not served to program attendees and staff of the after school program do not consume sugar-sweetened beverages at the after school program site. shall remain in effect only until January 1 2018 unless a later enacted statute that is enacted before January 1 2018 deletes or extends that date.) Establishes criteria for receiving state funds for building projects. 990,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Marketing Restrictions,Community,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 1016,5,1,2011,Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs,Nutrition,School Nutrition,Community,(Abstract - Amends regulations regarding the reservation allocation and compliance monitoring of the Federal and State Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs. These regulations provide a tax credit for farm worker housing and building projects that are near public transit a farmers market a full scale grocery store.  ) (BillHistory - )
1017,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Public Safety,Work Place,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)
1018,5,1,2003,School District Governing Boards: Contracts,Nutrition,Farm Direct Foods,School/After School,(Abstract - Prohibits the governing board of a school district from entering into or renewing any contract for the sale of carbonated beverages or nonnutritious beverages and certain nonnutritious food within the school district unless the governing board provides written notice to parents or guardians of pupils regarding the contract and provides those persons with an opportunity to comment on the contract at a public hearing at a regularly scheduled board meeting.) Provides that no General Fund monies shall be used to fund the program.) 1030,5,1,2013,School Nutrition,Nutrition,Nutrition Standards,School/After School,"(Abstract - ""Amends existing law to include a requirement for including a nutritious snack in the high school after-school programs and a physical activity element.  Amends the requirement banning competitive food sales to only  before or after the school day and adds skim milk and whole grains to the list of foods that may be sold.  Removes 2 percent milk from approved beverages."") 1032,5,1,2010,Farmers' Markets: Electronic Benefit Transfers,Nutrition,Agriculture and Farming,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Allows an interested collective group or association of produce sellers that is Food and Nutrition Service authorized and in a flea market farmers' market or certified farmers' market to initiate and operate an electronic benefit transfer system acceptance system in the market. Provides that an individual produce seller in a market is not prohibited from operating his or her own individual system acceptance activity as part of that seller's personal business customer transaction offering. ) (BillHistory - 02/25/2009 - INTRODUCED.;03/12/2009 - To ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE.;04/01/2009 - From ASSEMBLY Committee on AGRICULTURE with author's amendments.;04/01/2009 - In ASSEMBLY. 1033,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Food Restrictions,Community,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 1047,5,1,2005,Vehicles: State Wilderness Areas,Obesity,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Requires a person who violates a state or federal regulation that prohibits entry of a motor vehicle into all or portion of an area designated as a federal or state wilderness area is guilty of a public offense and shall be punished by fines. Authorizes the court to order the impoundment of the vehicle used in a third or subsequent offense for a specified period of time. Prohibits assignment of a traffic violation point count to a conviction for unauthorized entry of a motor vehicle into wilderness areas.) 1062,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Access to Healthy Foods,Medical and/or Hospital,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. 1065,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Food Restrictions,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)

1112,5,1,2003,Physical Education,Physical Activity,Physical Education Requirements,School/After School,(Abstract - Requires the Department of Education to encourage K- 12 schools to provide quality physical education that develops the knowledge attitudes skills behavior and motivation needed to be physically fit for life. Requires the department to encourage those schools to provide extracurricular physical fitness programs and clubs and to encourage the use of school facilities for physical fitness programs. Authorizes test results to be given orally.) 1121,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Public Safety,Medical and/or Hospital,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Authorizes a district or county superintendent to use certain funds.) 1145,5,1,2010,Schools: Pupil Nutrition: Availability of Tap Water,Obesity,Access to Drinking Water,School/After School,(Abstract - Requires a school district to provide access to free fresh drinking water during meal times in school food service areas by a specified date unless the governing board of a school district adopts a resolution stating that it is unable to comply with this requirement stating the reasons why it is unable to comply. Requires the resolution to be publicly noticed on at least two consecutive meeting agendas and approved by at least a majority of the governing board. ) (BillHistory - 02/19/2010 - INTRODUCED.;03/11/2010 - To SENATE Committee on EDUCATION.;04/14/2010 - From SENATE Committee on EDUCATION:  Do pass to Committee on APPROPRIATIONS.;05/10/2010 - In SENATE Committee on APPROPRIATIONS: To Suspense File.;05/27/2010 - From SENATE Committee on APPROPRIATIONS:  Do pass as amended.;06/01/2010 - In SENATE. 1161,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Health Insurance Coverage,Work Place,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 1185,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Nutrition,Initiatives and Programs,School/After School,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. (BillHistory - 06/13/2012 INTRODUCED. 06/18/2012 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH. 07/03/2012 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted as amended to Committee on APPROPRIATIONS. 08/06/2012 In ASSEMBLY. 1206,5,1,2010,Federal and State Low Income Housing Tax Credit Laws,Nutrition,Agriculture and Farming,Community,(Abstract - Amends rules regarding the procedures for reservation allocation and compliance monitoring of the Federal and State Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs and establishes policies and procedures for use of the Tax Credits to meet purposes of the Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Provides for low income housing to have access to: transit; a public park; a full scale grocery store/supermarket where staples fresh meat and fresh produce are sold; and a weekly farmers market.) (BillHistory - )
1207,5,1,2005,Farmers' Markets,Nutrition,Farm Direct Foods,Community,(Abstract - Extends the provisions of existing law that provides it is unlawful for any person operating under the provisions governing certified farmers' markets to commit certain acts and that requires every market operator to remit to the Department of Food and Agriculture a specified fee.) 1209,5,1,2005,Retail Food,Nutrition,Farmers Markets,Restaurant/Retail,(Abstract - Relates to the Uniform Retail Food Facilities (CURFFL) Law that provides for the regulation of health and sanitation standards for retail food facilities and that prohibits a food facility from opening for business without a valid permit issued by the local enforcement agency. Repeals the CURFFL and recasts and revises its provisions by creating the Retail Food Code.) 1212,5,1,2011,General Site Development Grant,Obesity,Appropriations,School/After School,(Abstract - Reinstates the grant program for general site development costs available to school districts under the School Facility Program. Decrees that there can't be more than six parking spots for each new classroom built. Also allocates funds for paths for pedestrian use necessary for a safe route to school as judged by several criteria.  ) (BillHistory - )

1215,5,1,2001,Land Use: Energy Conservation,Nutrition,Medical Care,Community,(Abstract - Makes technical nonsubstantive changes to local restrictions on the use of solar energy systems. Makes technical nonsubstantive changes to provisions regarding subdivision design to account for future passive natural heating and cooling opportunities in the subdivision. Requires all subdividers to dedicate additional land to provide bicycle paths for residents. Authorizes local ordinances to require land within any subdivision to be dedicated for local transit facilities.) 1219,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Physical Activity,Initiatives and Programs,Work Place,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. Adopted by SENATE. *****To ASSEMBLY; 03/23/2006 To ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH; 06/13/2006 From ASSEMBLY Committee on HEALTH: Be adopted; 06/26/2006 In ASSEMBLY. Read third time. Adopted by ASSEMBLY. To Enrollment; 06/28/2006 Enrolled; 06/30/2006 Chaptered by Secretary of State; 06/30/2006 Resolution Chapter No. 73)

1232,5,1,2005,Senate Concurrent resolution                 <br>,Obesity,Health Insurance Coverage,Community,(Abstract - Resolves that the Legislature supports the following 10 Steps to a Healthy California: (1) promotion of the importance of physical activity and healthy eating; (2) participation of every child in physical activities; (3) only offering healthy foods and beverages to students; (4) only healthy foods should be marketed to children ages 12 years and under; (5) produce and other fresh healthy food items should be affordable and available in all neighborhoods; (6) neighborhoods and communities should support physical activity including safe walking stair climbing and bicycling; (7) healthy foods and beverages should be accessible affordable and promoted in restaurants and entertainment venues; (8) health care providers and insurers should promote physical activity and healthy eating; (9) employees should have access to physical activity and healthy food options; and (10) the Legislature recognizes the unique ability of the California Task Force on Youth and Workplace Wellness to help the state serve as a role model for increased physical activity and improved nutrition and wellness throughout the nation.) (BillHistory - 02/06/2006 INTRODUCED; 02/06/2006 To SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 Withdrawn from SENATE Committee on RULES; 03/15/2006 In SENATE. Read third time. 1236,5,1,2010,Federal and State Low Income Housing Tax Credit Laws,Physical Activity,Appropriations,Community,(Abstract - Amends rules regarding the procedures for reservation allocation and compliance monitoring of the Federal and State Low-Income Housing Tax Credit Programs and establishes policies and procedures for use of the Tax Credits to meet purposes of the Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Provides for low income housing to have access to: transit; a public park; a full scale grocery store/supermarket where staples fresh meat and fresh produce are sold; and a weekly farmers market.) Prohibits on or after a specified date oil shortening or margarine containing specified trans fats for specified purposes from being stored distributed or served by or used in the preparation of food.) 1251,5,1,2007,Pupil Nutrition: Trans Fat,Nutrition,Farm Direct Foods,School/After School,(Abstract - Prohibits a school or school district through a vending machine or school food service establishment during school hours and up to 1/2 hour before and after school hours from making available to pupils in kindergarten or any of grades 1 to 12 inclusive a food containing artificial trans fat. Prohibits the use of artificial trans fat in the preparation of a food item served to those pupils. Excludes food provided as part of a USDA meal program.) 1271,5,1,2007,Food Facilities: Trans Fat,Nutrition,Farm Direct Foods,Community,(Abstract - Requires every food facility except a school cafeteria to maintain on the label for any food or food additive that is or includes any fat oil or shortening for as long as this food or food additive is stored distributed or served by or used in the preparation of food within the food facility. Prohibits on or after a specified date oil shortening or margarine containing specified trans fats for specified purposes from being stored distributed or served by or used in the preparation of food.) 1276,5,1,2014,Office of Farm to Fork,Nutrition,Disparities/Equity,School/After School,(Abstract - Establishes and provides appropriations for the Office of Farm to Fork within the Department of Food and Agriculture which seeks to work with stakeholders within the state food system to increase the amount of agricultural products available to underserved communities (particularly urban and rural) and schools in the state. The program also seeks to identify promote the acceptance of food assistance programs such as WIC and CalFresh at certified farmer’s markets. It also includes provisions for increasing information technical assistance and resources.) Specifies the powers and duties of the agency.)
